nodes.text: Contact comfort rather than nursing or food-related drive is the primary variable driving the development and persistence of infant affectional bonds to the mother or mother surrogate

Neonatal and infant rhesus macaque monkeys can be used to experimentally analyze the stimulus variables underlying affectional responses because they are more mature at birth and show similar development of nursing, contact, clinging, perception, fear, and learning to humans

Constructed two mother surrogates: a soft warm cloth-covered terry-cloth surrogate providing contact comfort and a wire-mesh surrogate providing nursing postural support but minimal contact comfort; both could be heated and could provide milk depending on condition

Experimental design: newborn monkeys given simultaneous access to both cloth and wire surrogates with feeding manipulated so that for half the infants the cloth mother lactated and for the other half the wire mother lactated; time spent on each surrogate and behavioral responses were automatically recorded and tested across multiple paradigms and over long retention intervals

Control and additional groups included single-cloth-mother rearing, single-wire-mother rearing, and a control group raised without any mother surrogates until ~250 days to assess effects of late introduction

Rationale and background claim: prevailing drive-reduction theories posit that attachment to the mother is a derived response based on association with primary drives like hunger, but these theories do not account for persistence and generalization of human and primate affection
When given simultaneous access, infants overwhelmingly preferred and spent far more time clinging to the cloth surrogate than to the wire surrogate regardless of which surrogate provided milk

Across multiple behavioral tests (fear tests, open-field, modified Butler box visual preference, puzzle-solving for access) infants consistently sought the cloth surrogate as a haven of safety, base for exploration, and primary contact object, independent of nursing status

Infants with lactating wire mothers showed decreasing responsiveness to the lactating wire mother and increasing responsiveness to the nonlactating cloth mother with age and experience, contradicting predictions of drive-reduction theory

Infants reared only on wire mothers had biologically adequate nursing and normal weight gain but showed softer stools suggesting psychosomatic effects and displayed far less contact time and security behavior than cloth-mother reared infants

Control infants raised without surrogates initially showed fear and avoidance when cloth and wire mothers were introduced at 250 days but within days developed strong preference and long contact times with the cloth surrogate, though their peak contact levels were lower than infants mothered from birth

Affectional bonds to the cloth surrogate were highly persistent and resistant to extinction: preferences for cloth over wire persisted across 165 to 185 days of testing and were retained after separation, showing minimal waning and long-term retention
